Caption: Fig. 1. Using projections to correlate different data sets that do not have explicit relation among instances. An initial projection is created using a few instances of each data set (music and images). Then, the relation amongst selected instances is deﬁned by grouping images and music in the visual space, creating an explicit correlation. Considering this initial manipulation, the projections of the entire data sets are accomplished and the correspondence is settled. Finally, the lists of corresponding elements are used to produce slide shows where the images and related music are played in a synchronized manner.
Fig. 2. The three main modules that compose the LAMP’s framework.
Fig. 3. The stress produced by LAMP when the number of control points ranges from 1% to 25% of the total of instances in the data set (see Table 1 for details about the data sets).

Fig. 13. Image and music correlation: A few representatives (control points) of music and pictures are selected from the corresponding data sets (top left) and placed in the visual space (top middle). User interacts with the sample pictures and music so as to bring close the ones to be correlated (top right). LAMP maps music and picture according to the user provided grouping (bottom right). The user can brush multiple regions in the visual space (bottom middle), each one corresponding to the pictures and music the will make up a slide show (bottom left).

The user can brush multiple regions in the visual space (bottom middle), each one corresponding to the pictures and music the will make up a slide show (bottom left).
